The question asks if we can infer "If the wolf was in the den, then the bear was in the case," which is the converse of the original statement. The converse of a conditional statement "If P, then Q" is "If Q, then P" (Q → P).

In classical logic, the truth of a conditional statement does not imply the truth of its converse. The original statement (P → Q) only tells us that whenever P is true, Q must also be true. It does not provide any information about what happens when Q is true. Therefore, we cannot infer the converse (Q → P) from the original statement (P → Q) without additional information.
